title: photographer-natalie-luke-gives-1-400-coldstream-primary
story: A BORDERS photographer has raised more than pound, for a local primary school after completing her ldquoLockdown Doorstep Portraits Challenge.Natalie Luke, , from Duns, started taking pictures of people on their front doorsteps in May.She has now used the income to give a donation of pound, to Coldstream Primary School.ldquoWhen I handed over the cheque I was very excited and happy, knowing that the money raised was being donated to a wonderful place, Miss Luke told the Border .When the UK went into lockdown in March, Miss Luke was forced to close her photography business, Natalie Luke Photography, as summer events were cancelled or postponed.:The Borders woman rowing across the Atlantic in a boat made of plastic bottlesBut when restrictions began to ease, she saw an opportunity to dust off her camera."Instead of being stuck in the house, I thought I would pick up my camera again and help raise some money for a good cause, said Miss Luke.She added: "By the time I started the challenge in May the country had been in lockdown for two months, so I hoped it would give the local community something to look forward to."We have never had to experience anything like this before in our lives."Documenting it and keeping photographs will allow us to reflect back on those memories in years to come."From the very beginning it was planned to be a fundraiser and I knew I wanted to raise money for a good cause within my local community."After setting up her business five years ago, Miss Luke has photographed some of the key moments in many peoplersquos lives, including baby portraits, family photos and weddings.One of the benefits of launching her Lockdown Doorstep Portraits Challenge was that she was able to revisit previous clients, albeit in a dferent way."A large portion of my business is based around newborns, children and family photography and it was lovely to see old and new clients being eager to participate, said Miss Luke."I couldnt imagine what all the children must have been experiencing during the lockdown.ldquoThey wouldnt have properly understood why they couldnt go to school to learn, see their friends and family members, go out and play and just be kids.:Why this Peebles mum has organised her own half marathonOn August , Miss Luke visited Coldstream Primary School to hand over a super-sized cheque to head teacher Chris Reid.Miss Luke said: "Coldstream Primary School is where all the children attend and they do an amazing job with their education, so they were the perfect fit for the donation.In a Facebook post on the schools page, Mr Reid said: "A huge thank you to Natalie Luke Photography who handed the school a cheque for pound,."This was raised doing her doorstep photographs."Thank you to all who helped by getting their photos taken."

title: coronavirus-selkirk-high-school-issues-contact-tracing-letter
story: A BORDERS school says contact tracing is being carried out following a new case of COVID-.Selkirk High School head teacher Jamie Bryson has penned a letter alongside Lesley Munrondash Scottish Borders Councilrsquos service director for young people, engagement and inclusion.As first reported by Radio Borders, the letter urges parents to be on their guard, adding that children should not attendthey ndash or members of their household ndash display virus symptoms.The letter reads: ldquoFor your information, we are aware of NHS Contact Tracing activity within the Selkirk High School community. This is in relation to a single case of COVID-.ldquoThe purpose of this communication is simply to raise awareness and ensure that the wider school community is vigilant at all times to COVID- symptoms as a matter of course.:Supermarket worker tests positive in the BordersThe letter goes on to read: ldquoPlease note that due to patient confidentiality we cannot disclose any further information, but please be assured that all appropriate measures are in place to protect young people and staff as far as possible.ldquoAdditional cleaning will be completed prior to the start of the school day on Monday.ldquoIt is clear that the threat of COVID- remains signicant and this requires ever present vigilance.ldquoIt is vital that no child attends schoolthey are displaying any COVID- symptoms. These are a new persistent cough, temperature and or loss or change in ability to taste or smell.ldquoWith this in mind your child children must not attendthey or any household member is showing symptoms of COVID- and the school must be advised of their absence.ldquoIn these circumstances you should seek a COVID- test as soon as possible via the government portal www.gov.uk get-coronavirus-test and all household members should self-isolate. You should let the school know the result of the test as soon as you receive it.ldquoThe situation will be monitored closely and we will work with NHS Borders to ensure the most appropriate advice is given to you and updates provided as required.ldquoThanks for your ongoing cooperation.According to data from Public Health Scotland, there was one new confirmed case of COVID- in the Borders on August .There have been  cases in the region since the outbreak began, with a total of  deaths.

title: gyms-pools-reopen-scotland-august-31---key-changes-need-know
story: NICOLA Sturgeon last week confirmed the long-awaited reopening of gyms, swimming pools and indoor sports courts.The First Minister revealed they will open their doors from August  ndash brought forward from a previous estimated date of mid-September.But a number of things will change as we continue to live in the lsquonew normalrsquo, with Scottish Government officials setting out new guidance for customers and staff to follow.Herersquos what to expect on your :The overall capacity may be reduced to maintain physical distancing ndash with only a limited number of people allowed in the building.There may be less gym-organised classes to allow for time to clean equipment and space.Everyone using the facilities will have to provide their details for Test and Protect.Equipment that cannot be cleaned will be removed.Hand sanitising stations at entrance exit points and other key areas.Changing rooms should be avoided where possible.Showers should be avoided and only usedessential.Communal showers may be closed.Saunas and steam rooms will remain closed.Use of shared items ndash including towels, robes, balls, weights, rackets, scoring equipment and sports clothing ndash should be avoided unless they can be cleaned between users.In exercise spaces, temporary floor markings should be used to maintain physical distancing.Existing and new members may be given COVID- inductions to the facilities.Full details can be found on the Scottish Government website here.

title: face-coverings-scotlands-schools-explained-guidance-say
story: Pupils across Scotland will have to wear face coverings in schools from next week,the Scottish Government has confirmed.The updated guidance comes off the back of new public health advice, including World Health Organisation guidelines.So who has to wear a mask  And is it mandatory Here, we detail out everything you need to know:Who should now wear coverings In secondary schools, adults and all pupils moving around the school, such as in corridors and communal areas, where physical distancing is dficult to maintain.However, like in shops and other indoor spaces where masks are mandatory, the Scottish Government accepts there will be some exceptions - including people with certain health conditions.When will this come into force The new guidance will apply from Monday, August .Will schools provide coverings Nicola Sturgeon said plans will be in place for schools to provide extra coverings, to ensure no-one goes without a covering who wants one.Concerns were raised over a lack of social distancing in schoolsWhat about on school transport The new guidance says that all children aged five and over should wear a face covering on dedicated school transport. This is now brought into line with the public transport guidance.What about primary school children With the exception of school buses as outlined above, the new guidance in schools only applies to secondary school pupils.Do they need to be worn in class While staff and students can continue to wear face coveringsthey wish to, they will not generally be necessary in the classroom.This is because there is greater scope for physical distancing and face coverings can have an impact on teaching.However it remains the case that where adults cannot keep m distance and are interacting face-to-face for a sustained period , face coverings should be wornCan a child be excluded for not wearing one It is expected that the guidance will state that pupils should notbe excluded from schoolthey do not wish to wear a face covering.Can someone help my child with their covering Education Secretary John Swinney said:ldquoSchools will be asked to ensure children and young people have clear instructions on how to put on, remove, and store face coverings."Any staff member or pupil will still be able to wear a face covering when they wish to do so."John Swinney confirmed the new guidanceWhy is this being done Mr Swinney added:ldquoThere is increasing evidence that face coverings can provide some protection for the wearer as well as those around them."We also know that some pupils have found it very dficult to physically distance when moving around school, which could increase the risk of transmission of the virus."And on school transport, as on public transport, there can be mixing between dferent age groups."What  was said Mr Swinney said:ldquoWe want to continue to protect what we have achieved in suppressing the virus and re-opening schools, and to do the best for children in schools."Alongside this change to the wearing of face coverings, we need to reinforce the importance of maintaining high standards of cleaning, personal hand and respiratory hygiene and physical distancing, where possible."In situations where there is a local cluster, use of face coverings throughout the day may be required.ldquoThe position will be kept under review to ensure that our approach remains commensurate with the evidence and the levels of transmission in Scotland.

title: british-made-swappable-battery-technology-leads-e-scooter-launch
story: An e-scooter featuring British-made swappable batteries has been launched as plans to trial the technology get under way.German firm Tier hopes to deploy its new model in cities across the UK later this year along with a network of box-like charging stations, where users can swap out batteries to earn free rides.It comes as new regulations enabling trials of rental e-scooters came into force at the beginning of July, to assess whether e-scooters reduce motor traffic and what impact they have on the safety of users and those around them.The fully automated charging stations can be placed inside existing businesses to boost customer visits, such as in convenience stores or cafes, with all required electricity provided by the host covered by Tier, the company said.London-based startup Pushme ndash acquired by Tier earlier this year ndash developed the technology and has a manufacturing base in Aylesbury, Oxfordshire.The new scooters will debut in Tampere, Finland, where a fleet of , devices will be supported by a network of  charging stations across the city.By the end of , the company plans to roll out its swappable battery technology across all its operations, which currently sit at more than  cities across nine countries.vw,vw,px, px"Launch of the new Tier e-scooter took place in central London on Tuesday Tierrsquos latest e-scooters feature a foldable helmet, as well as indicator lights on the steering bar and back fender to signal the riderrsquos direction to other road users.ldquoToday marks a step change in safe and sustainable travel around our cities, said Lawrence Leuschner, chief executive and co-founder of Tier.ldquoBy integrating this new kind of swappable battery technology, we are building a Europe-wide charging network that allows users to play an active part in adopting climate-neutral travel and building better cities.ldquoAt the same time, by hosting the charging pods in local businesses, we are helping high streets to recover from lockdown.ldquoThis is a crucial step in Tierrsquos electric revolution to make mobility better.ldquoIt is our plan that in time our charging network will not just service e-scooters, but other vehicles too.As part of a -month trial of e-scooters across the UK, only rentals are allowed on roads, limited to .mph.Riders who participate in the pilots will need a full or provisional car, motorcycle or moped licence, must be aged at least  and will be urged to wear a helmet.Emma Drackford, communications director at Electrical Safety First, said: ldquoAs our lives become increasingly electric, it is important consumers only purchase items such as e-bikes and e-scooters from reputable retailers.ldquoWhilst cities around the country trial public hire schemes, privately owned models, which are not yet legal for use on public land, will need to be charged at home and consumers should be wary of purchasing low quality, substandard imitations which could pose a signicant fire risk..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: British-made swappable battery technology leads e-scooter launch

title: pm-calls-end-wetness-bbc-chief-says-proms-decision-right
story: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has called for an end to ldquoself-recrimination and wetness as the BBCrsquos chief said it was ldquoright to remove lyrics from some traditional anthems at the Last Night of the Proms.The BBCrsquos director-general Lord Hall said the decision to perform new, orchestral versions of Rule, Britannia! and Land Of Hope And Glory was a ldquocreative one.But he confirmed that the issue of dropping songs because of their association with Britainrsquos imperial history had been discussed.His interview aired after the Prime Minister voiced his concern over the issue, saying he wanted to get his thoughts ldquooff my chest.vw,vw,px, px"Prime Minister Boris Johnson during his visit to Appledore Shipyard in Devon ldquoI just want to sayhellipit is correct, which I cannot believe that it really is, butit is correct, that the BBC is saying that they will not sing the words of Land Of Hope And Glory or Rule, Britannia! as they traditionally do at the end of The Last Night of the Proms.ldquoI think itrsquos time we stopped our cringing embarrassment about our history, about our traditions, and about our culture, and we stopped this general fight of self-recrimination and wetness, he said during a visit to Devon on Tuesday.ldquoI wanted to get that off my chest.There will be no live audience to sing along and wave flags at the September  concert because of coronavirus restrictions.Lord Hall said it was a ldquomiracle that Proms boss David Pickard had put together a fortnight of live performances amid the pandemic.Asked whether there had been a discussion about dropping songs because of their association with Britainrsquos imperial history, he replied: ldquoThe whole thing has been discussed by David and his colleagues, of course it has.vw,vw,px, px"BBC director-general Lord Hall ldquoThe point is theyrsquove come to the right conclusion, which is itrsquos very, very hard in an Albert Hall that takes over , people to have the atmosphere of the Last Night of the Proms, where a whole audience normally sing along, he told the BBCrsquos media editor Amol Rajan.ldquoItrsquos quite hard creatively and artistically to make that work. I think theyrsquove come to the right conclusion.ldquoWho knows what will happen next year. I suspect it will be back.ldquoThe fact is we have come to the right conclusion, which is a creative and artistic conclusion, he said on BBC Radio rsquos World At One programme.Rule Britannia and Land of Hope and Glory are highlights of the Last Night of the PromsShare concerns of many about their potential removal and have raised this with @BBCConfident forward-looking nations donrsquot erase their history, they add to itmdash Oliver DowdenAugust , Earlier, Business Secretary Alok Sharma suggested the BBC use subtitles so viewers can sing along at home.ldquoPersonally, I would like to see the lyrics sung and of course it is always possible to put lyrics up as subtitles on the screen sopeople want to they can join in at home, he told Times Radio.The former chairman of the Equality and Human Rights Commission, Trevor Phillips, told the station that the BBC panicked when it came to issues of race.ldquoIt has no confidence. The principal reason it has no confidencehellip is that there is no ethnic ersity at the top of its decision-making tree, he said.Just for future reference, this is how you do Land of Hope and Glory.#LNOP#LastNightOfThePromspic XxykxIqHmdash BBC PromsSeptember , ldquoWhat you have is rooms full of white men panicking that someone is going to think they are racist.The BBC said there had been ldquounjustied personal attacks on social media on Finnish conductor Dalia Stasevska, who will be at the helm of the Last Night this year.ldquoDecisions about the Proms are made by the BBC, in consultation with all artists involved, it said.ldquoThe Proms will reinvent the Last Night in this extraordinary year so that it respects the traditions and spirit of the event whilst adapting to very dferent circumstances at this moment in time, it said.In light of the recent speculation about the Last Night of The Proms, here is a full statement: https:t.co WCfXlbntdkpic WszwwRxxmdash BBC PromsAugust , ldquoWith much reduced musical forces and no live audience, the Proms will curate a concert that includes familiar, patriotic elements such as Jerusalem and the national anthem, and bring in new moments capturing the mood of this unique time, including Yoursquoll Never Walk Alone, presenting a poignant and inclusive event for .The national anthem and Jerusalem will still be sung during the event, which will air on BBC Radio  and on BBC One and feature soprano Golda Schultz and the BBC Symphony Orchestra at the Royal Albert Hall in London.Earlier, after The Sunday Times reported that the songs could face the axe, Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden tweeted that he had ldquoraised concerns with the BBC.ldquoConfident forward-looking nations donrsquot erase their history, they add to it, he said.But TV choirmaster Gareth Malone suggested Rule, Britannia! was outdated, tweeting: ldquoItrsquos time for Rule Britannia! to go.Rule, Britannia! ndash strongly associated with the Royal Navy ndash is deemed problematic by some because of Britainrsquos role in the slave trade.Anyone for some socially-distanced Mozart The BBCSO strings were reunited for the first time since lockdown yesterday, and the fullorchestra will rehearse on Monday! #Thanks to our Orchestra Manager @singingninfor the video # pic hJrSOTSmdash BBC Symphony Orchestra  ChorusAugust , It has lyrics such as Britons ldquonever shall be slaves and that ldquowhile thou shalt flourish great and free, the dread and envy of them all.Land Of Hope And Glory features the music of Edward Elgar and the lyrics of Arthur Benson, including ldquoThine Empire shall be strong and ldquoGod, who made thee mighty, make thee mightier yet..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: PM calls for end to  uwetness u as BBC chief says Proms decision was right

title: broadband-improvements-lined-towns
story: Openreach wants to make ultra-reliable and gigabit-capable full fibre broadband available to places throughout Scotland, including Cockenzie and Port Seton, Prestonpans, Tranent, Belhaven and Dunbar.It is hoped having access to some of the fastest broadband speeds in Europe will boost post-Covid economic recovery.Robert Thorburn, Openreachrsquos partnership director for Scotland, was pleased to see work progressing.He said: ldquoWersquove already upgraded hundreds of thousands of homes and business across Scotland to full fibre.ldquoAs well as keeping the existing network running throughout the Covid- crisis, our engineers have, safely and with social distancing in place, continued building the new infrastructure to make sure that as lockdown restrictions ease, our network is there to support families, businesses and the economic recovery.Work is expected to get under way in many of the announced locations within the next - months, although, due to the size of the build, some places will see work continue into .Paul Wheelhouse MSP, the Scottish Governmentrsquos connectivity minister, said: ldquoDigital Connectivity has played a vital role in supporting our efforts to keep people safe and connected during lockdown, and will play a pivotal role in plans for our strategic economic recovery from the pandemic, maintaining jobs and livelihoods and creating new skills and opportunities.ldquoThis rollout of gigabit-capable full fibre broadband access enabled by Openreach to these more rural areas is welcomed.To view the full list of market towns and villages included in the announcement, go to www.openreach fibre-broadband

title: changes-planned-high-street-scotmid-store
story: The High Street supermarket is looking to make changes inside its store, while also increasing the number of spaces in the neighbouring car park.Proposals for the store and car park are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.A spokeswoman for the business said they had discussed the project with the local community council ahead of submitting the planning application.She said: ldquoThe work being proposed will help improve our offer in the community by improving the store entrance and external appearance of the store and by refitting the store in accordance with our latest branding.ldquoWe also recognise the limitations of the existing car park and propose to make our car park larger and easier to access.ldquoWe also propose to move the funeral unit which is located in the car park into the main building.The number of spaces in the car park will nearly double as it increases from  to .Some work has already been carried out inside the store, with energy efficient refrigeration cabinets with doors installed.

title: preston-athletic-players-swap-boots-bicycles-fundraiser
story: Members of Preston Athletic FCrsquos squad got on their bikes to raise money for the club and the NHS on Saturday, August .A dozen players, as a relay team, cycled from Dunbar Unitedrsquos New Countess Park through East Lothian, Midlothian and Edinburgh before reaching the finish line at their home ground, the Pennypit.Kai Austin was among those setting off from the Seasidersrsquo ground at about am but had to make a quick substitution before kick-off.He said: ldquoI had not checked my bike for about a week beforehand.ldquoI was putting it into the car and noticed the back tyre was flat.ldquoI thought we would pump it up when we got there.ldquoAfter we arrived, my girlfriend drove away and I was walking along and noticed the tyre was flat again.Fortunately, one of Kairsquos team-mates for the cycle had a spare bike and they were quickly able to get on the open road.The fundraiser came about with players deciding to visit  football grounds ndash the home of  teams ndash ahead of the   season.The first stop was at Millfield , before going on to Foresters Parkand New Recreation Park .The second group of cyclists ventured into Midlothian and ticked off Kingrsquos Park , Newbattle Complex , New Victoria Park , Newbyres Park , New Dundas Parkand Ferguson Park .Nathan Stokes, who plays in midfield and up front, was among the third group, who completed the Midlothian section by travelling on to Penicuik Park .Then it was into the Capital and Paties Road , Meggetland , Saughton Enclosureand Christie Gillies Park .Finally, the Edinburgh section was complete with a visit to Ainslie Park Stadium , St Marks Parkand Peffermillbefore ing to East Lothian and Olivebankand the Pennypit.Nathan, , said: ldquoTo get to Peffermill, we came down Cameron Toll.ldquoFrom the Commonwealth Pool, it is all downhill and by that point my legs were screaming.ldquoFor me, it was a nice relaxing run down there and when we reached Peffermill we knew it was only  minutes to Musselburgh and then another - minutes to the Pans. Getting to East Lothian was definitely a psychological boost.The cyclists finished at the Pennypit shortly after pm, where they were met by the participants from the earlier legs.Right-back Kai, who lives just metres from the ground in Prestonpans, was among those at the finish line. He said: ldquoWe had the people that did the cycle and some people there that were not able to do it because of injury.ldquoThe club put on a socially distanced get-together and put on some sausage rolls and pies.ldquoWe were sitting in the stand and were there for them arriving and cheered them in.Nathan, of Wallyford, was delighted to reach the finish line, with the cyclists completing  kilometres over the eight hours.He added: ldquoThe aim was to get pound, and then we raised pound,.ldquoWe are really chuffed and ideally I would like to raise another pound so the cash is split into pound each.ldquoI think I was chuffed and on Saturday Hearts tweeted us and wished us luck.ldquoWe have got a few Hearts fans in the team so they were happy.To support the good cause, go to justgiving crowdfunding prestonathletic

title: paralympian-maria-lyle-takes-presenting-role-podcast
story: Maria Lyle is not hanging up her running spikes but has teamed up with journalist Gary Heatly to create This Ability Podcast.The monthly show sees the duo chat with a iety of guests about what it is like living with a disability and shines a light on some amazing achievements.Maria, who has spastic diplegic cerebral palsy, said: ldquoIt is something that I have never done before.ldquoGary approached me with the idea of doing it and highlighting how disabled people live their lives and to make it come across that a disability is not such a negative thing. It is something new and I have really enjoyed it and learning from Gary.The third episode of the podcast is being recorded this month.Each episode has been created during the coronavirus pandemic lockdown, with Gary, Maria and their guests in separate locations and speaking over Zoom.The first episode featured Maria, who lives in Dunbar, and Gary, who is based in Edinburgh, discussing their own personal experiences of living with cerebral palsy.Then, last month, the hosts spoke to actress Amy Conachan, who has appeared in more than  episodes of Hollyoaks as Courtney Campbell.Former Dunbar Grammar School pupil Maria said: ldquoShe was really nice and friendly. It was interesting to hear her story about acting and her journey to television, which has been very successful, and how she deals with her disability.Mariarsquos love of athletics began when she was at Dunbar Primary School, with her mum, Susan, taking a PE lesson.She previously said: ldquoOne day, when I was in about primary four, we had a multi-stage fitness bleep test-type thing to do.ldquoI wasnrsquot any good at anything and everything and I wasnrsquot looking forward to it at all ndash even though my mum was the teacher. Running at that stage usually ended with me falling over  per cent of the time and cutting my knees.ldquoBut I thought I would have a go and basically I was the last pupil standing at the end of the test.Since then, she has won medals at the Paralympics in Rio de Janeiro in  and two gold medals at the World Para Athletics Championships in Dubai last year, in the T m and m.The -year-old was due to represent Great Britain at the Paralympics in Tokyo this month before the international event was put back a year due to the coronavirus.She said it was nice to speak to people outside the sporting world about their lives and was looking forward to welcoming more guests onto the podcast.Gary, , who was previously editor of The SCRUM Magazine, praised Mariarsquos efforts on the new podcast. He said: ldquoShe has been absolutely brilliant.ldquoThe first podcast was just me and her having a chat about our own experiences. We are  years apart so we have dferent experiences.To listen to the podcast, go to play.acast s this-ability-podcast

title: new-group-tackling-issues-river-esk
story: The Esk River Improvement Groupwas set up following concerns about mine water discharge, sewage, and discharge from combined sewage overflows.Its first meeting, held online last week, was hosted by local MSP Colin Beattie.The discussion was attended by key stakeholders such as the Scottish Environment Protection Agency , Scottish Water, the Coal Authority, East Lothian Council and community councillors, amongst other interested bodies.Mr Beattie said: ldquoThe issues with the River Esk have been ongoing for a long time and I know that my constituents are frustrated that no permanent solutions have been found.ldquoI wanted to establish a group where we look at the overall health of the River Esk and bring together those who are already working to make improvements to the quality of the water. It is much easier to see a result when we are all working collectively to resolve an issue and that is the exact purpose of this forum.ldquoIt is important to me that members of the community are involved and I am pleased we have many representatives from our community councils working with the group, and also some local establishments such as Newbattle Abbey College and Musselburgh Racecourse. It is heartening that so many people are willing to commit to volunteering their time to make active change on this matter.He added: ldquoI was pleased to discuss what progress was being made on these matters already, as well as thinking forward to establish what we need to do to stop these issues arising again in the future.ldquoAll constituents also have a part to play by ensuring they understand what not to flush down the toilet and by helping to educate others. Lessening the amount of sewage debris, which is often full of flushed wipes and sanitary towels, is an essential part in maintaining the cleanliness of the river.ldquoI am very pleased that the Coal Authority are putting in place a system to clean the mining discharge from Junkiersquos Adit, and also that Scottish Water, supported by SEPA, are actively working to undertake clean-ups on the Esk and improve their existing systems to prevent sewage spills going forward.ldquoI would like to remind my constituents that this group is not a substitute for reporting issues, and thatconstituents see pollution in the river then they should report this urgently to SEPA via their pollution reporting tool at www.sepa.org.uk EnvironmentalEvents or get in touch with Scottish Water directly, either through their website or by calling   .ldquoConstituents have a vital role to play by reporting problems when they see them, which allows them to be investigated more quickly and this will allow Scottish Water to undertake urgent clean-up.ldquoAnyone who would like to know more about the group is welcome to contact me at colin.beattie.msp@parliament.scot and I will gladly add them to ERIGrsquos mailing list.

title: nearly-50-m-co-stores-shut-haddington-musselburgh-survive
story: The company, which has been in Haddington for more than  years and in Musselburgh for more than , had appointed administrators in April as the coronavirus outbreak forced the closure of most UK retailers for nearly four months.Positively, Haddingtonrsquos Court Street store and Musselburghrsquos High Street branch have survived.Andy McGeoch, MCorsquos chief executive, said: ldquoIt quickly became clear that the best way to save most jobs and most stores was to enter administration, with a new company acquiring the assets of the old business, and this process has now been finalised.ldquoCovid has been by far the biggest challenge our family business has faced in almost  years, and I am really pleased that we have been able to maintain a presence in over  communitiesldquoCovid- means many people donrsquot feel comfortable travelling on public transport or visiting busy city centres and that can be good news for local High Street stores like MCo.ldquoThatrsquos why we are looking at ways of working in partnership with other local retailers to highlight the tremendous range of shopping that can be found in communities like this all over the country.The administration process, which is being managed by Deloitte, will see the number of MCo stores drop from  to .About  people are being made redundant from a total workforce of more than ,.The Musselburgh store has seven members of staff, with the Haddington branch employing  people neither store is affected by the restructuring.

title: plans-prestonpans-town-centre-revealed
story: The measures are being brought in by East Lothian Council under its Spaces for People scheme.It says that due to the limitations on space in the town, it is important that more spaces are introduced for people on foot, in wheelchairs and on bikes.A council spokesperson said: ldquoSupporting safe physical distancing for essential journeys and exercise is vitalwe are to suppress Covid-.ldquoIt will also improve opportunities for walking and cycling, creating environments that foster healthy and sustainable travel habits.Since last month, several new measures have already been introduced to Prestonpans, including a town-wide mph speed limit which also covers Cockenzie and Port Seton.Additional traffic calming measures were also brought in to allow the council to respond to requests for the use of public space, make it easier for people to cross the roadnecessary to maintain social distancing and support walking and cycling to school.Over the next few weeks, more measures will be introduced.On the south-east side of Prestonpans High Street, outside the Filling Station sandwich shop, the pavement will be widened and parking spaces for four cars removed the existing disabled parking space will remain.A three-metre-wide hard-surfaced temporary cycle route will be introduced adjacent to the north-western side of Edinburgh Road, between Prestonpans and Cockenzie.A temporary mph speed limit is also set to be introduced for Edinburgh Road, with regular traffic calming measures along the route.Measures to increase space for pedestrians on busy routes to school and at the school gates are being considered plans include widening pavements.More details on routes to school and the chance for members of the public to comment on them are available at bit.ly afajKcBefore the end of the year, the council hopes to explore the option of installing a public ebike hire station for eight bikes at Prestonpans Community Centre, Prestonpans High Street and in Cockenzie on Edinburgh Road and East Lorimer Place.Fiona OrsquoDonnell, ward councillor, said: ldquoI want to see businesses in our high streets able to operate safely.ldquoThese measures will help them do that with space for people to pass when queues are forming outside.ldquoFeeling they can shop and use other businesses safely will, I hope, encourage more people to use them, keep them open and protect jobs.ldquoThe mph limit will keep us all safer when out and about. I have already seen that it is making it easier for pedestrians to cross the road.ldquoI know it requires a change from drivers, and want to appeal to them to stick to the new limit.Brian Weddell, chair of Prestonpans Community Council, said: ldquoIrsquom very supportive [of the plans], particularly the slowing of traffic as wersquove been campaigning with Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry Community Councils for a couple of years to get traffic speeds reduced entering the villages, so hopefully it will lead to that.He also expressed his support for the cycle path plans.

title: musselburgh-mcdonalds-plan-rejected-east-lothian-council
story: The fast food chain applied for planning permission to build the new restaurant, which would open  hours a day, next to the townrsquos Tesco store as it looked to draw customers from the supermarket into its drive-thru.However, claims by the chainrsquos representative Paula Reed-Smith that the number of visits to the restaurant from Musselburgh Grammar School, on the other side of the supermarket, would be lsquolimitedrsquo were disputed by local councillors.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee met virtually to discuss the plans for land to the east of Inveravon Terrace, off Olivebank Road, and questions were asked about why McDonaldrsquoswas looking to place a drive-thru in a town centre and near a secondary school.Ms Reed-Smith told the committee: ldquoWe anticipate pedestrian visits from the school will be limited.ldquoWe did not choose the location because of Musselburgh Grammar School, we chose it because of the location of Tesco.However, ward councillor Andy Forrest told the committee it would be a short walk to the restaurant for youngsters.He said: ldquoFrom the back door of the school to the front door of the new McDonaldrsquostakes a -second stroll.Councillor Stuart Currie, fellowMusselburgh ward member, who called in the application which was recommended for approval by planning officers, said children would ldquogravitate to the restaurant.He said: ldquoAbout  kids go to Tesco at lunchtime. We will have hundreds of kids walking through Tesco car park to McDonaldrsquos, they will gravitate to it.Musselburgh Area Partnership and Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council both objected to the plans, which drew  objections and two statements of support.Local resident Lynda Baird spoke in favour of the new restaurant, telling the committee that as a mother of four teenage children she welcomed it.She said: ldquoI worked for McDonaldrsquosand the food was always top quality the hygiene standards and training offered is also top quality.Ms Baird also hit back at social media ldquobullies who she claimed had attacked her and anyone who spoke out in favour of the drive-thru on Facebook.She told the committee: ldquoThere has been social bullying of people in support of McDonaldrsquos. I am badly dyslexic and was severely bullied by those against it.ldquoIf you donrsquot want it, donrsquot go, but donrsquot bully people who do want it.But Kirsten Leask, another local resident, urged the committee to reject the McDonaldrsquosapplication, pointing out that the health and wellbeing of children was at the heart of council policy.She said: ldquoThe proposed developmentrsquos location is within walking distance of not just Musselburgh Grammar School but three primary schools.Iain Clark, from the area partnership, also pointed out that three McDonaldrsquosrestaurants near Musselburgh were based out of town centres and away from schools, adding: ldquoWhy should Musselburgh be the exception Bernard Harkins, from the community council, pointed out thatMussselburgh town centre was an Air Quality Management zone because of pollution caused by traffic congestion pre-Covid- lockdown.He said: ldquoDuring lockdown we did see pollution levels fall, with the weekend of May  seeing zero levels recorded. We should be building on that.The councilrsquos roads department came under fire for ruling that traffic attracted by the drive-thru would not have a ldquosignicant impact on current congestion after using a peak hour model to measure it.Councillor Katie Mackie, Musselburgh ward member, said that she had recently timed a drive along theof the road which would be used by the drive-thru and it took her more than five minutes.She said: ldquoI have had more complaints from local residents about this application than any other issue since I was elected in .ldquoThere is no peak hour in Musselburgh town centre, congestion is round the clock.The planning committee voted to go against officersrsquo recommendation and refuse the application on the grounds of its impact on traffic, air quality and noise impact on the amenity of the surrounding residences.

title: east-lothian-council-peoples-energy-form-money-saving-partnership
story: East Lothian Energy will see the local authority work alongside Peoplersquos Energy to offer affordable, sustainable and fair energy for residents throughout the county as part of a joint commitment to eradicate fuel poverty.The new initiative sees Peoplersquos Energy, in association with the council, offering a special iable and fixed tarf that is discounted from its regular tarfs and available exclusively to East Lothian residents.The offer equates to potential savings of up to pound annually compared with the current energy price cap , based on Ofgemrsquos medium typical domestic consumption values energy usage.Councillor Norman Hampshire, council spokesman for the environment, described the scheme as ldquoquite a unique initiative.He said: ldquoEast Lothian Energy gives county residents the exclusive opportunity to purchase affordable, sustainable and fair energy. We hope this will be attractive to householders across a mix of tenures ndash including tenants and homeowners.ldquoAs well as saving money and helping to reduce fuel poverty, East Lothian Energy is a great way of enabling customers to support the environment and tackling climate change ndash a key priority for us as a council.ldquoThat is because all of the electricity comes from  per cent renewable sources.ldquoEast Lothian Energy customers will receive automatic Peoplersquos Energy membership ndash with  per cent of their profits being paid back to domestic members through an annual rebate.David Pike, CEO and co-founder of Peoplersquos Energy, based at Danderhall, said: ldquoWithin East Lothian, it is estimated that almost a quarter of householdsare living in fuel poverty, equating to , homes.ldquoWith this new affordable tarf for East Lothian residents, we have the potential to reduce the fuel poverty gap in the area quite considerably.ldquoPeoplersquos Energy is a social enterprise that puts people and the planet before profits.ldquoWersquore delighted to have the opportunity to partner with East Lothian Council to help make a positive change.To sign up, visit peoplesenergy eastlothian

title: coronavirus-scotland-face-coverings-become-law-schools-workplaces
story: Nicola Sturgeon told her coronavirus briefing yesterday that it was ldquounder review, as the Scottish Government attempt to strike the right balance between ldquobeing as normal as possible and the learning experience for young people.It comes after a number of confirmed COVID- cases were reported in pupils across the country ndash with classes and even whole schools having to self-isolate.Face coverings could become mandatory in secondary schoolsA public health expert has since said that the mandatory wearing of masks in workplaces and secondary schools should be considered to keep them open.Coverings are compulsory in many indoor settings including shops, on public transport and in places such as cinemas, galleries, museums, libraries and banks.Professor Linda Bauld said they could be considered in other settingslevels of coronavirus go up.What did she say Asked in an interview on BBC Radio Scotland whether introducing face coverings in workplaces should be considered to allow more people to get back to work, she said: ldquoI donrsquot think we should rule it out."I thinkcases go up and we need particular settings to reopen that canrsquot, for whatever reason, face coverings indoors absolutely, but at the moment those sectors that can work from home ndash thatrsquos the message that I agree with ndash should continue to do that.Prof Bauld, who is professor of public health at the University of Edinburgh, said the virus is at a ldquovery low level in terms of where we are in Scotland and that while it is circulating it is localised in terms of the rise in cases.Face coverings are already mandatory in some situationsShe said the best way to protect schools is to keep virus levels low, but that face coverings could be considered for secondary school pupils to avoid having to pause education.Prof Bauld said: ldquoIn terms of the cases that wersquore hearing about in school pupils, these are not cases that are occurring because pupils are catching the virus in the school setting, they are cases that are arising in the community, and when we have the virus circulating in the community even at low levels we know that children and young people may get it and then thereforethey go into the school they are still carrying it.She added: ldquoI thinkwe wanted to talk about, for example, face coverings for secondary school pupils rather than closing a school, thatrsquos another step we might want to discuss, thatrsquos being discussed in other places, but we donrsquot need it at the moment."We just have to think about what are the alternatives to having to pause education again because wersquore all trying to avoid that.Itrsquos now mandatory to wear a face covering in more indoor public places in Scotland.This video explains where you must wear one #Detailed guidance # https:t.co QmCaYPog pic YWJXeeHWhat did the First Minister say During her daily briefing yesterday, the First Minister addressed the concerns over cases in pupils ndash as well as responding to images of crowded hallways and playgrounds.Ms Sturgeon said the introduction of face masks in schools would not be ruled out.She said: "When we see anything like that, directors of education in relevant councils will be contacted to make sure they are applying all of the right guidance."We will keep all of this under review, and that includes face coverings, so that we are striking the right balance between as normal as possible in what is still an abnormal situation and learning experience for young people, but with the right mitigations in place."

title: muirfield-host-womens-open-first-time-2022
story: The world-famous course, which has held the menrsquos event  times, has been confirmed as the venue for the prestigious competition in .A decision to allow female members at Muirfield for the first time by the Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers was taken in . Previously, women had only been allowed to play the course as guests or visitors.A vote the previous year had seen a vote to scrap the clubs men-only policy fall narrowly short of the required two-thirds majority.Following that vote, the venue was removed from organisers The RAs rota for hosting The Open ndash it was reinstated following the  reversal of the men-only policy.Martin Slumbers, chief executive of The RA, was delighted with Muirfield receiving the  Womens Open, a decision which was announced on the eve of this yearrsquos event, which is being played at Royal Troon.Next year, Carnoustie will host the competition, which was won last year by Hinako Shibuno, with Muirfield then welcoming players in .Walton Heath , St Andrewsand Royal Porthcawlwere also announced as future venues.Mr Slumbers said: ldquoWith our partners at AIG, we have a real ambition to grow and elevate the AIG Womens Open for the benefit of the worlds leading golfers and so we are excited to confirm our intention to play the next five championships at these renowned courses.ldquoIt has truly been a collaborative effort from all the venues involved to make this schedule possible and the flexibility that they have shown in adjusting their own calendars has been vital in allowing us to confirm our plans for the championship through to .ldquoWe are grateful for their support, particularly during a time when golf has been impacted by the ongoing pandemic, and we look forward to working with these venues to deliver an outstanding experience to be enjoyed by everyone involved in the AIG Womenrsquos Open.North Berwicks Catriona Matthew won the tournament in , when it was hosted at Royal Lytham and St Annes.Muirfield, Walton Heath and Royal Porthcawl will all be hosting the womenrsquos major championship for the first time.Muirfield, near Gullane, has a prestigious history of hosting Major championships, having last held The Open in .Phil Mickelson lted the Claret Jug on that occasion and the course also hosted The Curtis Cup in  and , as well as the Vagliano Trophy in  and .Councillor Jeremy Findlay, who lives in nearby Gullane, described it as ldquogreat news for the club and great news for East Lothian.He said: ldquoThis part of East Lothian is not known as Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast for nothing.ldquoIt is the greatest stretch of golf courses in the whole of Scotland,not the whole of the UK, and Muirfield is the jewel in the crown that continues to attract visitors from all over the world, who want to play Muirfield, Gullane, North Berwick and Dunbar.ldquoWe saw the Ladies Scottish Open event [at The Renaissance Club, near Dirleton, last week] being held without spectators.ldquoIt is great to have it here but not having spectators is a great shame because that adds to the whole atmosphere and the draw.ldquoHopefully, in two yearsrsquo time, we have a vaccine [for Covid-] and we are back to as close to normal as possible.

title: storm-ellen-high-winds-expected-east-lothian
story: Although the storm is expected to be worst in the west, East Lothian and other parts of south-east Scotland are also due to be impacted.The Met Office has issued a yellow be aware warning of wind for East Lothian covering the period from am to pm tomorrow.The Met Office says that strong winds on Friday are expected to lead to some travel disruption and could possibly disrupt power as well.It says that some travel delays are likely, while some short term loss of power and other services is also possible."Itrsquos likely that some coastal routes, sea fronts and coastal communities are affected by spray and or large waves," the Met Office adds, as well as "some damage to trees, with debris on roads possible given the time of year".Although the storm is not predicted to be as severe as some of those in the early part of the year, the unseasonal nature of a storm of this type striking in summer is expected to bring its own problems, as trees are in full leaf and therefore could suffer more damage than usual.

title: nina-young-walking-north-coast-500-teapot-trust-memory-sister-verity
story: Nina Young has laced up her walking boots and aims to complete the picturesque North Coast  in aid of the Teapot Trust.The charity was founded by her mum and dad, Laura and John, nearly  years ago after the death of their daughter Verity.The eight-year-old spent much of her short le in hospital coping with illness and managing the effects of her treatment, first for lupus and then for cancer.Art gave Verity a way of expressing herself and was an essential coping strategy for the whole family, so John and Laura wanted to help other children and families who were struggling.Nina, who has been joined by friends and university coursemates during her fundraiser, said: ldquoAs a medical student, I really see how mental health takes a knock when you have physical health conditions to live with, every day of your le, constantly on medication or injections.ldquoThe Teapot Trustrsquos art therapy sessions really build great coping strategies for kids and so I am delighted that the money I am raising is going towards that.Nina left her home in Gullane at the end of last month to head to the starting point of Inverness.From there, she has headed north, covering an average of  mileseach day.She spoke to the Courier while walking between Melvich and Strathy, on Scotlandrsquos north coast, last Tuesday morning.The -year-old said: ldquoWith people doing lots of challenges during lockdown and raising money for charity, I thought: lsquoIf they can do it, why canrsquot I rsquoldquoMy flatmate and I had planned to drive the North Coast  before lockdown and that did not happen.ldquoMy sister Isla, she loves the song Irsquom Gonna Beby The Proclaimers and I was thinking what I could do for the Teapot Trust.ldquoIt is a small charity and struggling for funds with the pandemic.The former Gullane Primary School and Loretto School pupil set off from Inverness on July .However, not everything has been straightforward along the way.She said: ldquoOn day three, we were coming down a hill and my knee twisted.ldquoI thought that was it.ldquoI made it to the next campsite and the next day I could not finish the walk.ldquoA friend had come up to help take our bags for a day and he gave me a lt and my friend finished the day off.ldquoI was worried it was all over but wersquove survived with ice, ibuprofen and a knee brace.ldquoIt has got better, especially as you get the distance and you are making progress.Originally, Nina set a fundraising target of pound, before she set off for the Highlands.Already, that target has been smashed, with the University of Edinburgh student hoping to complete the route by the end of the month.She said: ldquoIt seemed like a lot of money.ldquoWe have broken it already, which is pretty cool.ldquoWe have been amazed by the kindness of people donating and it is a great motivation.ldquoI get an email every time someone donates and you get a little lsquopingrsquo on your phone.ldquoIt is worth the sore feet and hopefully it keeps coming in.The Teapot Trust, which is based in Musselburgh, has helped more than , children and young people in Scotland since its launch, giving them art therapy sessions.Nina said of her late sister: ldquoVerity was so bubbly. I was quite young as well ndash I was nine years old when she died.ldquoEverything was fine and OK in some ways because I was young and sheltered from the stress of the hospital.To support the good cause, go to www.teapot-trust.org fundraisers we-will-walk--miles
